awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Development of a bioprocess technology for the production of a non-corrosive and environmentally benign deicing chemical from waste byproducts
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project is reduced costs of road and highway infrastructure repairs and environmental benefits from the use of a low-cost biodegradable and non-corrosive deicer substitute for salts. Deicing chemicals are applied to roads in winter for safety. Typical salts are highly corrosive to concrete, reinforcing steel, and bridge decks, and hence cause billions of dollars in road repair and infrastructure rehabilitation costs.  Because these salts do not biodegrade, they accumulate in the environment and increase salinity in lakes and ground waters, as well as in water supplies. Acetate-based chemicals are effective deicers with minimal corrosion and environmental effects, but they can be expensive to produce.  This project will repurpose wastes to produce a low-cost deicer for reduced infrastructure costs and enhanced environmental quality.

The proposed project will provide a new cost-effective low pH bioconversion process for the production of acetic and lactic acids from carbohydrate wastes. There are currently no industrial bioconversion facilities for the production of acetic acid due to the high recovery costs for the sorption or extraction of the acid from the broth at neutral pH. This project will advance bioconversion of sugars at sufficiently low pH values where the product recovery efficiency is high. Acid recovery by adsorption on resins or liquid-liquid extraction is about twelve times more efficient with the proposed process than with anaerobic fermentations that operate at neutral pH. This project will develop a process to utilize abundantly available organic and inorganic wastes in the production of the acetate deicer. Hemicellulose, the second most abundant carbohydrate in nature, is not utilized in ethanol fermentations due to the low efficiency of bioconversion. Hemicellulose hydrolysate will be used as substrate in the proposed process. Continuous fermentations at low pH values will be optimized for high organic acids productivities. Multicomponent adsorption studies will be conducted to optimize the schemes for the recovery of the organic acids from the fermentation broth.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview: Biomass is an abundant renewable resource available for the production of biofuels and biochemicals. This project is aimed at the utilization of lignocellulosic biomass and wastes in the production of platform chemicals such as acetic and lactic acids, and acetate based biodegradable road and aircraft deicing chemicals as derivative products. Acetic acid is at present being produced synthetically using high-pressure and high-temperature process with a high carbon footprint. An innovative low pH bioconversion process was utilized in this project to produce acetic and lactic acids from biomass hydrolysates, and the products were extracted using liquid-liquid extraction with ternary amine. Lime softening water plant residuals were used to react with acetic acid to produce calcium and magnesium acetates for use for road deicing applications. The biodegradable and non-corrosive deicer produced can replace currently used chloride deicers that are causing environmental pollution and infrastructure damage. This project provides important contributions in transitioning from a “take-make-waste” linear economy to a circular economy with a lower carbon footprint.

Intellectual Merit: Hemicellulose, the second most abundant carbohydrate in lignocellulosic biomass is at present underutilized or discarded. The use of biomass wastes containing significant amounts of hemicellulose such as oat hulls, brewer’s spent grain (BSG), and corn stover were studied in this project. Acid hydrolysis of corn stover was conducted at different temperature and pH conditions, and the hydrolysate containing predominantly C5 sugars was converted to acetic and lactic acids using an innovative low pH bacterial fermentation process. Cyclic adsorption on polymeric resins, liquid-liquid extraction (LLE), and reactive LLE were studied for the effective extraction of the acids from the fermentation broth. Studies were conducted on the use of inorganic wastes from water treatment operations to react with acetic acid to produce calcium and magnesium acetate deicers. This transformation is controlled by surface reaction of acetic acid with calcium carbonate in the water plant sludge and the transport of reactants and products. Optimum operating conditions were developed for maximizing the conversion of the reactants in the production of the deicer.

Broader Impacts: This project will have positive social, economic, and environmental impacts from reducing the cost and carbon footprint associated with the production of organic acids, and the production of a value-added deicer product from water plant residuals. About 60 million tons of deicers are used worldwide to provide safe transportation of people and goods during snow events in winter. The chloride salts that are principally used cause billions of dollars in infrastructure repair and rehabilitation costs due to increased corrosion of bridge steel and concrete. These inorganic salts do not biodegrade and accumulate in the environment causing damages to aquatic ecosystems and human health. Society will benefit from the health and aesthetic effects associated with a cleaner environment, and the reduced infrastructure costs that will result from the use of benign acetate-based deicers developed in this project. At present acetic acid production is based on the use of natural gas as raw material. The ability to produce such high-value chemicals from biomass will provide a path to reach net-zero goals by reducing reliance on fossil fuels for the production of organic chemicals.

Project Outcomes: A method to utilize the hemicellulose fraction of lignocellulosic materials in the production of platform organic chemicals, acetic and lactic acids was developed. At present, the hemicellulose fraction of lignocellulose is discarded or used for low value uses such as animal feed or as fuel. The methodology developed uses acid hydrolysis of corn stover or other biomass to produce C5 sugars such as xylose, arabinose, etc., that are converted to acetic and lactic acids using a low-pH bacterial fermentation process. The acid extraction efficiency is about eight times higher at low pH than at neutral pH that is used in most bacterial fermentations. Cyclic adsorption processes with polymeric resins and activated carbon as adsorbents were evaluated for the extraction of acids from the fermentation broth. Adsorption processes were found to be technically feasible but not economically viable due to the significant energy requirements in the desorption process. LLE using solvents such as ethyl acetate, pentanol, octanol, etc., were studied, but found to be unsuitable due to ineffective recovery of the solvents due to azeotrope formation. Reactive LLE was found to be a suitable method for the effective extraction of acetic and lactic acids from the fermentation broth.

Lime softening operations, used in water treatment to reduce hardness of water supplies, result in the generation of large amounts solid residuals that contain calcium and magnesium salts. A process was developed for the reuse of these residuals in the production of a biodegradable and non-corrosive road deicing chemical. This project developed optimum operating conditions for the effective reaction of this waste material with acetic acid to produce a marketable deicer product.
